description: Before you start to set up a charity make sure that you know it is the best option for what you want to do.

details.body:
Know who you will help and how you will help them

If your organisation benefits the community, it does not mean that you can automatically set up a charity.

This is because not everything that benefits the community is charitable.

You must have specific aims (known as ‘charitable purposes’) to set up a charity.

You can set up a Community Interest Company (CIC) instead. This is a company that helps the public but is not a charity.

Read the rules on setting up a CIC to see if it is a more suitable structure

Check if a charity is already doing what you want to do

Find out if any charities are already doing what you want to do.

Working together can be more effective than setting up a new charity. For example, so there are not two charities competing for resources.

Find a registered charity to see if you can work together.

You should also search the internet to find charities who are not registered with the Charity Commission.

Check charity restrictions

Check that being a charity will not stop you doing things you want to do.

For example:

  • you need to follow charity law and give up to date information on your work and finances
  • charities cannot carry out certain political activities, like campaigning for a change in government
  • you must make independent decisions about your own work if you plan to work with others
  • trustees, anyone connected to them, or the founder, cannot receive personal benefit unless it is ‘incidental’ and you make independent decisions on personal benefit and properly manage conflicts of interest

Alternatives to setting up charity

Set up a social enterprise

A social enterprise is a business that has social, environmental or community-based objectives. The rules on ‘charitable purposes’ do not apply.

Set up a social enterprise

Set up a named fund or a trust instead of a charity

You can set up a named fund if you want to raise money for a certain cause.

This saves the time and effort of setting up and running a charity.

Set up a fund through a community foundation

If you have more than £10,000 to donate you could set up a Charities Aid Foundation (CAF) charitable trust.

Set up a CAF charitable trust

steps.title: Check if setting up a charity is right for you

contents: @{href=/government/publications/what-makes-a-charity-cc4; text=Check if your organisation can be a charity}

contents.text: Trustees are responsible for the operation of your charity. They must show they understand their legal requirements.

contents: @{href=/guidance/trustee-board-people-and-skills; text=Check who's eligible to be a trustee and what skills they need to have}
@{href=/government/publications/the-essential-trustee-what-you-need-to-know-cc3; text=Read about your trustees' legal responsibilities}

steps.title: Find out how to choose a charity structure

contents.text: There are rules on what words you can use in your name.

contents: @{href=/setting-up-charity/name-your-charity; text=Check what you can call your charity}

contents.text: You cannot register a name that's the same as or similar to another charity.

contents: @{href=/find-charity-information; text=Check the names of registered charities}

steps.title: Choose a name for your charity

contents.text: Your ‘purposes’ describe what your charity is set up to achieve.

contents: @{href=/guidance/how-to-write-charitable-purposes; text=Find out how to write your charity's purposes}

steps.title: Decide and write your charity's purposes

contents.text: The governing document is a set of rules that explains how your charity is run. It needs to include your charity's structure, name and purposes.

contents: @{href=/guidance/how-to-write-your-charitys-governing-document; text=Find out how to write your governing document}

contents.text: Your organisation must be able to show that it benefits the public.

contents: @{href=/guidance/public-benefit-rules-for-charities; text=Check how your organisation must benefit the public}

steps.title: Make sure you meet the 'public benefit requirement'

contents.text: You must apply to register your charity with the Charity Commission if either:

contents: @{text=its income will be at least £5,000 per year}

contents.text: You can register your charity’s details with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) to get tax back on things like Gift Aid donations.
